titlepage.author: Encoded finding aid prepared by Michelle Sweetser, December 2003

did.unittitle: Lon G. Nungesser Hope for Humanity Papers 1970-1989
did.abstract: The Lon G. Nungesser Hope for Humanity Papers, 1970-1989 comprise correspondence, drafts of unpublished and published manuscripts, ideas for research projects, family history material, publishers' contracts, placement files, and copies of his three books: Homosexual acts, actors and identities (Praeger, 1983), Epidemic of courage: facing AIDS in America (St. Martin's, 1986), and Notes on living until we say goodbye: a personal guide (St. Martin's, 1988). The papers reflect Nungesser's struggle against homophobia and particularly his battle with AIDS and coping with terminal illness. Correspondents include Dana H. Bramel, Stuart Kellogg, and Philip G. Zimbardo.

repository.corpname: University of Michigan Library (Special Collections Research Center)

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Papers were donated by Lon Nungesser in 1988 and 1989.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
Original audio cassettes have been digitized and the digital surrogates are available for researcher use in the Special Collections Reading Room.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan. Permission to publish must be obtained from the copyright holder(s).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Hope for Humanity Papers, University of Michigan Library (Special Collections Research Center)

bioghist.p: Lonnie Gene Nungesser was born in Springfield, Mo., on May 30, 1953, to a family living below the poverty level in the Ozark Mountains. He left home at the age of fifteen, graduated from Mountain Grove (Mo.) High School in 1971, and entered the U. S. Coast Guard, serving until 1973. He was licensed as a Southern Baptist minister in 1969. In 1975 he received his Associate's Degree from the College of Alameda (Ca.), where the previous year he had been elected the first Caucasian student body president. In 1979 Lon earned a B.A. in psychology from Stanford University and, in 1982, an M.A. in social psychology from the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

Lon left Stony Brook in early 1983 because of faltering health. In October of that year he was diagnosed as having Kaposi's Sarcoma and AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) and told he had only a few months to live. Since his diagnosis, Lon has dedicated his life to helping others survive the experiences he has lived through - coping with terminal disease and homophobia. To that end, Lon has written extensively. In addition to several unpublished works, he has three books: Homosexual Acts, Actors and Identities (Praeger, 1983); Epidemic of Courage: Facing AIDS in America (St. Martin's, 1986); and Notes on Living until We Say Goodbye: A Personal Guide (St. Martin's, 1988).

scopecontent.p: Although there is some memorabilia from his high school years and some personal mementoes, the bulk of this collection reflects Nungesser's struggle against homophobia, and particularly his battle with AIDS. The papers include published and unpublished writings, contracts with publishers, book reviews, drafts of research projects and grant proposals, correspondence, college placement files, articles and interviews, photographs, and clippings. There are two videocassettes, one of a call-in talk show with Nungesser as guest, and the other of Nungesser reading from Notes on Living until We Say Goodbye. In addition, there are two audio cassettes of radio interviews of Nungesser. The 1984 interview concerns Homosexual Acts, Actors and Identities and the 1988 interview discusses his battle with AIDS and Notes on Living until We Say Goodbye. These audio cassettes have been reformatted.

Nungesser is a prolific writer. There are several unpublished, book-length manuscripts in the papers, as well as dissertation and grant proposals and other writings. All relate to the social psychology of homosexuals, and several concern AIDS. Copies of Nungesser's three books have been cataloged for the Labadie Collection.

In April 1989, Lon began sending his correspondence and writings to the Department of Rare Books and Special Collections on computer disks. The files on these disks have been printed and those that did not duplicate materials already in the collection were interfiled. The disks are stored separately from the collection (in Case 2). Each of the printed files are labeled with the name of the file and its date of creation.
The papers have been divided into five series.

Series I. Personal/Biographical comprises Nungesser's statement of purpose for creating the collection, materials relating to his high school and college education, an unfinished family history project, a journal he began keeping in 1988 (parts of which are duplicated in the outgoing correspondence files), and an article about him and his Epidemic of Courage that appeared in Stony Brook magazine. There are several photograph and memorabilia albums containing recent and childhood photos of Lon, photos of his family, Bill Bullock, and places of significance to Lon, as well as his birth certificate, diplomas, clippings, greeting cards, etc. There is one restricted folder: Placement files and resume, 1975-86.

did.unittitle: The Nungesser Papers: Hope for Humanity. Statement of purpose, 1988
Mountain Grove High School, Mountain Grove, MO
Who's Who among Students in American Vocational and Technical Schools, 1974-75
University of California - Berkeley. Statement of purpose for application to graduate school, 1979
"Psychology of Sex Roles." Course proposal outline, 1981
Pacific Graduate School of Psychology. Admission application, 1986
Record of difficulty with landlord, John Renbourne, 1988
#5 "The life and times of Lonnie Gene Nungesser"
Ireland, Kevin. "An epidemic of courage: AIDS patient Lon Nungesser helps others confront an irrational killer," Stony Brook, vol. 1 #1, Spring 1987

scopecontent.p: Series II, Correspondence consists of outgoing correspondence, arranged chronologically, and incoming correspondence arranged alphabetically. Tora K. Bikson, Michael Denneny, Christine Friedlander, Stuart Kellogg, Gustav Neumann, and Philip G. Zimbardo are the most extensively represented correspondents.

Series III. Writings contains published and unpublished works from 1977 to 1989 arranged alphabetically by title. Include copies of Nungesser's three books: Homosexual Acts, Actors and Identities, Epidemic of Courage: Facing AIDS in America, and Notes on Living until We Say Goodbye: A Personal Guide, as well as reviews and clippings about the books. Nungesser's unpublished writings cover a variety of topics, including homophobia, coping with terminal illness (particularly AIDS) and the associated stigma, and ethics in the medical profession. They vary in format from poetry and short articles to book-length manuscripts and grant proposals.

scopecontent.p: Series IV, Personal Appearances/Speeches is comprised of typescripts, clippings, videocassettes, and audiocassettes of speeches and interviews of Lon between 1979 and 1988.

did.unittitle: Gay Blue Jeans Day speech, May 1979
Gay Life radio interview (KSAN), (cassette tape) (HOPEAUD-001) Feb. 26, 1984
"The Resurrection of Inspiration," Outline for sermon Mar. 30, 1986
"Notes on Living" reading for Dept. of Psychology, Stanford University, (videotape) Mar. 19, 1988

scopecontent.p: Series V: Suubject Files, consists of several folders of materials on a variety of topics, including several issues of AIDS Treatment News, a bibliography of sources dealing with the psychology of coping with illness, and samples of resumes Lon created for other people. Also includes a file entitled "RAM: Reforming American Medicine--Defending the Right to Self-Knowledge" which contains articles about ethics in the medical profession, newsletters and fact sheets from Project Inform (San Francisco), and a short information sheet created by Nungesser.

did.unittitle: Medical records (ring binder and loose sheets)

Notes from a man with AIDS.

scopecontent.p: Reformatted use copies of original audio casettes. Originals have been restricted for preservation purposes.

accessrestrict.p: Original audio cassettes have been restricted for preservation purposes. CD access copies are located in Box 5.

did.unittitle: Photo Album One: The Early Years with Bill
Lon at "Duck Pond" in E. Setauket, N.Y., moments before leaving for CA, March, 1983.
Bill after helping Lon pack to leave for CA.
Bill's Holy Vows to Lon photo of Bill when we met
Bill in front of California wild flowers of Sonoma, California
Bill sitting on his first car, May, 1983
Lon & Bill at a pool party, Summer of 1983
Bill explaining the dive he is about to perform
Bill in the tuck and roll position - it was a perfect dive!
Bill in front of fire place at our home in Redwood City, California
Bill playing flute for an elderly woman at her home, 1985
Lon kicks back with fond company, 1985
Bill in Bobby Reynold's and Mark Wood's home on Valentine Day, 1984
Jasmine about to attack the camera!
Jasmine when she's tired of the flash
Squash bed in garden, with beans and a Nasturtium boarder
A part of our flower bed
Jasmine looking for a bathroom in fresh dirt - ugh!
Sister's plotting a scheme to get under the mesh net in to the fresh bark of the strawberry bed.
The start of a great corn and pole bean crop
Fall crop of broccoli, turnips and carrots
Jasmine's favorite position: The "please rub my tummy" position.
Sabrina in my Moss Rose bed - She was lucky I thought it was cute!
Fall colors show first on this berry bush
Lon a few days after AIDS diagnosis was confirmed
View of Golden Gate Bridge from North of Bridge
Where the Russian River meets Pacific Ocean
A tourist town in the Redwood forest North of S. F. 60 miles
Gigantic Redwoods along the Russian River
Another day at the Russian River
Another day of sun worship in the driftwood "beach condos" at San Gregorio
The driftwood shelters at San Gregorio
Sabrina giving Bill that "Don't you dare spray me!" look
Bill & Lon in their piece of paradise
Lon & Bill after Joe (Lon's former lover) died of AIDS
Sabrina in my moss rose bed - again!
Lon & Bill exchange a Christmas Kiss, 1984
Lon & Bill after Lon's visit to his Ozark Mountain home, June, 1985
Lon answering questions about coping with AIDS from a person recently diagnosed with the virus
Lon going to work as the manager of a job placement agency, 1985
Lon's desk at the placement and resume writing agency
Lon after receiving his first royalty check from Homosexual Acts, Actors and Identities, 1985
The royalty check itself was less than 20.00, and the mountain backdrop represents the effort it took to write and place the manuscript
Yes, the garden was bare, but oh what fun we had planning the next crop!
Lon (oops, the love handles are showing!)
The rocking chair that Lon built for Bill
- the star was designed to be geometrically exact Spring, 1986
The beginnings of a chicken coop
Bill trying to keep the cats out of his way while he built the chicken coop
I just had to start with baby chicks
The garden is ready to plant, Spring of 1986
Lon after tending the lettuce bed
Lon at his tulip bed, holding "Clarence"
Our Rhode Island Red pullets and a hybrid Leghorn (Clarence)
The house we lived in when Lon was diagnosed and planted the gardens
Lon with Dr. Cherrie Boyer, a graduate school mate
When I foolishly followed a city-dweller's advice and covered the garden with straw to prevent weeds; How the weeds grew under that straw!
Bill's renovated garage turned Summer House
All I asked for was a smile...but this will do!
1986 Summer garden: Okra, squash, corn and beans
Lon: The irrepressible conflict resolver. Typical mediation with both sides not wanting to be there!
Raising chickens has been fun, but what do you do with a dozen eggs a day!
Can you find the cantaloupes in this photo?
At last a photo of the moss rose without a cat!
Erica, the hen that laid multi-colored eggs
Lon letting the chickens roam the garden with Jasmine on guard
Photo Album Two: More Cherished Moments with Bill
The 8' tall Sunflowers I grew from tiny seeds
Summer '85 spice bed: Basil, sage, aloe vera, peppermint, scallions & parsley
Ruby the Rhode Island Red hen. She was my pet, and often produced double-yolked eggs.
The climbing gourdes produced bushels of Fall color.
An onion goes to seed, and Hollyhocks are mixed with Sunflowers for a colorful background
Summer squash & fflowers at their peak of blooming, 1985
Summer `85 Moss Rose, Marigolds and Hollyhocks
Petunias and Pansies in full bloom at the base of a pear tree.
A new hybrid flock of young pullets, a cross between Rhode Island Reds & Leghorns
Jasper, the friendly rooster with no concept of time - he would crow at all hours so we ate him!
The third summer we stringed all vines on trellis' or ropes - what a maze!
Try finding your way in this garden jungle!
My "Star Flower Bed" with Petunias, Marigolds, Pansies, Moss Rose, California Poppies, Sweet William, Carnations and Allisum.
Erica on the attack of a second crop of chicks walking in her food
Sitting among the flowers was one of my most peaceful activities
The pole beans are taking over!
The garage turned in to a summer house
More weeds florishing beneath the straw
The Star Flower Bed in transition
Onions & chives at their peak of production
Gourds climbing over a walk-way beside the garage/summer house
Onions & sage in bloom; twine awaits the climbing squash
An apricot retrieved from near-death by Bill's expert landscaping skills and knowledge of vitamin therapy
Summer crop fades and goes to seed
Towering sunflowers line the garden's outer edge
A well-tanned Bill stands tall beside a towering sunflower
Sage, rosemary, parsley, peppermint and basil
Green pole beans climbing early sweet corn with snow peas in front
Pole beans mixed with snow peas
Beans climbing behind okra and snow peas
Bill holding Ruby - which of these characters is most apprehensive?
Lon & Bill on the foot-bridge at Domanine Chandon plant in Napa Valley
Bill with his cats, Sabrina & Jasmine - 1986
Sabrina loved sleeping under the Christmas tree (1986) and waking to lots of trinkets to paw at, like an infant in a crib with mobiles hanging.
Lon in front of 1986 Christmas tree
Lon & Bill Chistmas day, at the Boardwalk in Santa Cruz 1986,
Lon gleefully showing the completed autobiographical manuscript, "Spectrum of Life".
Lon giving Bill a good morning toast before he goes off to work, 1986
Bill standing at Coit Tower in S. F., Fall of 1986
Lon pondering his 5th year with Bill
Bill posing in front of the flower arrangement Lon gave him for their anniversary
Bill and Lon at Coit Tower in S. F., Summer of 1987
Lon and Bill outside Chocolate factory, Summer, 1987
Billy enjoying the S.F. view from Coit Tower, Summer of 1987
Lon and Bill having a picnic in Menlo Park, California in the Summer of 1987
Lon and Bill in S. F., Summer `87
Lon & Bill sharing a loving Christmas Kiss, 1987
Lon & Bill standing in front of our 1987 Christmas tree
Lon & Bill knealing in front of 1987 Christmas tree
Bill at Shoreline Park in Mountain View, California, Feb., 1988
Lon at his work place, February, 1988
A brisk sunrise before a storm
A bright morning before a sunny day
Bill looking for the glimmer of a sunrise through the stormy clouds
Bill at 5 AM without his morning coffee
Seagulls floating gracefully in the clouds
Ducks heading for shelter from the on-coming storm
This walkway is closed to humans, and provides a peaceful shelter to the wildlife
These gulls search for a sunny spot in the stormy weather
The storm had chased away the birds, and I, too, soon left
As the clouds thinned this gull soared high above the water
If I can only climb a few feet higher each time...
Lon & Bill celebrate receiving the bound galleys for Notes On Living Until We Say Goodbye
Lon & Bill pose before Lon's first reading & signing for Notes...
Bill ponders the beauty of Nature

Bill awakened the morning of his 26th birthday to a decorated house. I had waited for him to fall asleep, then went shopping at all-night markets; it took nearly all night - these are the moments that brought strength to our love in the face of adversity
Bill tucks his wallet away as he plans to ride the thriller rides
Lon before entering the amusement park where I took Bill for his birthday gift
As I said in jest about this photo before Billy would pose for it, "A picture is worth a thousand words"
- Bill comes home from his first hospitalization for PCP; KS biopsy results came back positive on the same day Aug. 25, 1988
The exotic flower arrangement I got for Bill's second coming home after being hospitalized for toxoplasmosis encephilitis - 10/13/1988
Surrounded by life-giving love, Bill finds his reasons to smile

A trip to the Pacific coast after Bill's third hospitalization when he could walk along the sea as he resolved that God is values and awe for nature, and that prayer is thought turned to hope. (Oct. 7 - 12)
1988 Christmas tree brought to us freshly cut by Robin Amundson and her family
Photo Album Five: The Life and Times of Lonnie Gene Nungesser
Lonnie Gene Nungesser's birth certificate, born May 30, 1953 shortly after noon.

odd.p: (My mom claims that Dad made her finish milking and other chores before he would take her to the doctor, else I would have been born sooner!)

did.unittitle: Large arrow head for hunting deer, found in the corn fields of our land.
The hills that cover our land in the Ozark Mountains - this photo is taken where my ashes are to be spread, for it was one of my favorite places to contemplate life beyond my own.
Small arrow head used for hunting squirrels and spearing fish; I found this one near the opening of a natural spring.
The quotes were taken with me to recite while watching the sunrise pictured
A special sunrise before a storm
The beginning part of the path I walked to watch the sun rise
My sister Mary to my right, and brother Donnie behind us..
Kansas flat lands behind us, Donnie holding Mary as I sit to the side
Lon on left, age 2 Mary in center, 3 mths. Donnie on R., at 3 1/2
Mary's second birthday Mary on left, Donnie holding the cake for her, and Lonnie showing his disdain for having to face the bright sun
Lon on left, age 4 Mary Jane on right, age 2
A main street in my home town, Mtn. Grove, Missouri
Fall colors decorate the tree over-hanging Grandma's smoke-house
The third-generation home in which my father was born and I was reared
Neighbor Belle's tree - the change in color warns all that Winter is around the bend.
One of the quotes that inspired me as a child and still does
My Sunday school class - on a poor attendance day!
The Pleasant Hill Baptist Church, where I learned & eventually taught.
THE LAST SUPPER, a painting I did for my Mom when I was in 6th grade; my parents have recently had it framed, and it now hangs above their kitchen table
Certificate of License to Preach the Gospel Ministry
Lon after Coast Guard Boot camp training
The quote that inspired my daily leadership activities
Armed Forces I.D. card (Taken after they pulled all 4 wisdom teeth and filled 10 others!)
Lon before graduation from the College of Alameda, 1975
Lon on right, seated with his newly elected Coalition student government
Lon in "The 01' swimmin' hole" back home, age 22
Letter of admission to Stanford University
Lon & friends at trail head that leads through Bear Valley to the coast
Lon as "Rebecca, The Pregnant Pioneer Woman", Halloween, 1977
One of my dinner dates with Advocate owner, David Goodstien, Esquire
Sharing Christmas cheer at my home with Dr. Don Clark & family, 1977
Front page article reporting my activities on "Gay Blue Jeans Day"
Stanford BA degree, with Departmental Honors
Lon with Honors advisor, Dr. Philip Zimbardo
The quote that helped me get through Stanford's Honors Program
First annual award in honor of Community College founder Leland Medsker, given to a graduate who shows promise as a future University President
Tracy Kahn, Ph.D. and I acting out an S & M ritual on stage for the Dept. of Psych.
The final line up, choreographed by Joe, second from left.
Front page article from the Fire Island Villager, June, 1981
Lon sealing his leave of absence from Ph.D. program
Lon in his favorite spiritual place, the Stanford Chapel; quote below helped me fall asleep without anger many nights.
A quote that helped me realize the value of a friend
Lon in 1983 at Twin Peaks in San Francisco

This photo is flanked by quotes at the top and bottom that helped me through the weeks after my AIDS diagnosis. The photo was taken at a special luncheon hosted for Foreign Scholars during the days between my biopsy and diagnosis.
Lon & Bill among the flowers that enriched their lives in times of stress, and offered a distraction from tragedy when they needed tending.
A sorta-drunk Lon trying to convince Bill we really were not lost!
The Gladiolus was bigger than ever this year, and surrounded by Poppies and Bachelor Buttons
Lon (1985) on the tractor he learned to drive on
The Ozark Mountains on our farm in Srping
Lon two years after AIDS diagnosis behind the barn built by my Grandfather the year of my father's birth
A quote that I tucked in my wallet when I had to go to the doctor or visit a sick friend during the first two years after my AIDS diagnosis
My mom, Emma, peering from the milk barn she has spent most of her working life in
Mom & Dad (1985) inside the ol' milk barn
The Nungesser Family - front row, starting at left: Lonnie, Donnie, and Danny. Back row, starting at left: Brenda Sue, Mary Jane, Linda Lou, Mom & Dad (1985)

Lon on left, John David on right. John David was my neighbor and friend as a child. He is married now, and has built the cabin in background with the rocks and trees natural to the Ozarks. A few feet from his front door is a natural spring-fed pond so clear you can see the rainbow stripes on the trout.
Grandma Nungesser on far left, Lon in front, Emma in back/center, and Grandma Jarrett on far right - 1985
Grandma Nungesser holding this years prize white Kitten
"Planting Seeds of Justice" a poem by Lon G. Nungesser
"About the Author" from my second book.
Paperback jacket from Epidemic of Courage
Cloth jacket from Epidemic of Courage
The quote that drove me to complete Notes On Living
Every sunrise was special, and this one brought out the birds as it peaked over the mountains
A self-help brochure I designed for coping effectively
Bill was too giggly to give me a Christmas Kiss in 1987
Sandy and Bill under the Christmas tree - she makes him giggle just being in the same room. Only 11 months apart in age, they are as much friends as siblings.

Linda Lou gets married, From left: My brother Donnie, his wife; my brother Danny, his wife and one of their kids, Misty, in front; my Father; Linda the beautiful bride, Jim her new husband; my mother holding one of Mary's girls; Mary with another of her girls in front; Bob Rech, Mary's husband; Brenda Sue, Linda's identical twin with another of Mary's girls holding a basket of rose petals; Doug Selby, Brenda's husband. January 2, 1988.
Mom at age 53 Dad at age 57
This pier is a safe place for many Gulls away from gusty winds
Clipping of an article entitled, "Shelf Life."
A representation of how I see Bill when he is playing - soaring high above, free of physical reality
I spent 2 hours in thankful prayer at this magnificent sight
Photo & quote are the things that have kept me living with valor and dignity
Flyers distributed before my first signing for Notes...
A Display case in San Francisco
The audience gathers before I speak
Bill talking with another person from New York
After this appearance a few lingered to chat
